Award.AwardTitle: Understanding climate change through simulations and systems thinking

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration: This project is developing, refining and evaluating a suite of simulations and systems-thinking exercises which enable students to investigate earth's climate and human-energy systems and their complex responses to changes in forcing factors. Scientifically sound and easy-to-use software models provide rapid feedback as students grapple with system responses over time to a variety of input assumptions. The ability of students to assume the roles of multiple stakeholders and quickly explore 'what if' scenarios as climate sensitivity and forcing factors are varied promotes understanding of underlying systems concepts. The intellectual merit of this project lies in its well-grounded plans for active engagement of students which confronts them with common misconceptions of complex systems and promotes more-robust understanding of system dynamics. The broader impacts include ready availability of the software and approaches for adoption elsewhere and wide applicability of the approach across a range of disciplines.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Our project developed, implemented, and determined the efficacy of simulation-based approaches to learning about complex problems. While our approach can be applied to many different kinds of societal challenges, the tools we developed focused on climate and energy. This topic area is rich in science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM) content, while also being highly relevant to many academic disciplines and to society more generally.

Our simulations create immersive experiences in which students they take on the roles of decision-makers who are charged with meeting international climate and energy goals. In the World Climate simulation, students take on the roles of delegates to the United Nations climate negotiations. In World Energy, they make decisions as leaders of key energy and economic sectors. In both simulations, interactive computer models provide immediate feedback on the expected impacts of their decisions on the climate-energy system, enabling students to learn for themselves about how the system works.

We measured the impact of these simulation-based tools on student learning, focusing on World Climate. We found that the simulation enhanced student learning about climate and energy, their desire to learn more, and their motivation to engage with the topic in real life. These results held across many different types of educational and cultural settings around the world, with participants ranging from secondary school students to graduate students, scientists, business leaders, and policymakers. Our project has brought these simulation-based tools to more than 33,000 students in 74 countries around the world, including 155 faculty members and 2,691 undergraduate students in the United States.
